title.narrative: Strengthening sustainability of NPAS in Jamaica

description.narrative: Strengthening the operational and financial sustainability of the National Protected Area System

title.narrative: Strengthening the Operational and Financial Sustainability of the NPAS
Mid-term Evaluation for Strengthening the Financial and Operational Sustainability of the National System of Protected Areas

description.narrative: Strengthening the operational and financial sustainability of the national Protected Area System
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

Ultimate Outcomes: 0.1 NPAS operational sustainability measured by average METT score for all PAs based on the following definitions: High (75-100), Medium (55-74), Low (<55). 0.2 NPAS financial capacity measured by Financial Sustainability Scorecard. 0.3 Area of closed broad-leaf forest within NPAS. 0.4 Population of 4 indicator species; 0.4.1 Population of endemic Giant Swallowtail Butterfly (Pterouus humerus). 0.4.2 Population of Queen Conch (Strombus gigas). 0.4.2 Population of Black Bill Parrot (Amazona agilis). 0.4.4 Population of Yellow Bill Parrot (Amazona collaria). 0.5 Percentage area of living reef within 10 NPAS monitoring sites. Outcome1: 1.1 Increase in Protected Area Trust Fund (CBF) principal and annual disbursement to NPAS. 1.2 Amount of funds generated locally by the Local PA Trust Fund and % of the Trust Fund principal generated locally. 1.3 Annual government funding for PAs. 1.4 Annual non-government resources for PAs. 1.5 Local Protected Area Trust Fund 100% established and operational by 2016. 1.6 Number of Protected Areas with Business Plans that reflect NPAS standards. 1.7 Number of Protected Areas with mechanisms to generate revenue at the site level. 1.8 Extent to which operational plan for the PA system financial strategy developed (completed, partially completed, not done); . Outcome2: 2.1 Number of PAs with clearly designated lead and support entity. 2.2 Status of developing drafting instructions for umbrella PA legislation and the supporting legal framework (completed, partially completed, not done); . 2.3 Number of new PA landscapes declared and implementing management plans that reflect integrated landscape/seascape wide approaches to combating PA threats. Outcome 3: 3.1 Increase in PA management effectiveness measured by METT scores. 3.2 Number of PAs that contribute to and/or access biological information through the CBD Jamaica Clearing House Mechanism (JACHM). 3.3 Number of PAs with management plans that reflect

comment.narrative: Ultimate Outcomes: 0.1 METT score classification: 0 PAs scoring high; 4 PAs scoring medium; and 28 PAs scoring low 0.2 Financial Sustainability score (Part 2) for NPAS is of 53 of possible 225. 0.3 Closed Broad-leaf forest area is 88,000 hectares. 0.4 Population of individuals of: 0.4.1Endemic Giant Swallowtail Butterfly (Pterouus humerus), 0.4.2 Queen Conch (Strombus gigas). 0.4.3 endemic Jamaican BlackBird (Nesopsar niggerrimus), 0.4.4 Hawksbill Turtle (Eretmochelys imbricate). 0.5 Living Reef of 3% - 30%. Outcome1: 1.1.1 Protected Area Trust Fund (CBF) principal is $0 and 1.1.2 Annual disbursement to NPAS is $0. 1.2 No Local PA Trust Fund exits. Funds generated locally is $0. 1.3 Annual government funding for PAs is US$4,097,000. 1.4 Annual non-government resources for PAs is US$1,575,987. 1.5 No Protected Areas Trust Fund existing locally. 1.6 No PAs with business plans that reflect NSPA standards. 1.7 One PA with mechanisms to generate Revenue (BJCMNP). 1.8 No Operational Plan for PA system financial strategy available. Outcome2: 2.1 One (1) PA within the NPAS legal agreement designating PA management authority. 2.2 No Umbrella Legislation for NPAS. 2.3 No new coastal and marine PA landscape gazetted and implementing management plans that reflect integrated landscape/seascape wide approaches to combating PA threats. Outcome3: 3.1 METT Scores for 28 PAs and 4 Forest Regions as follows: Montego Bay Marine Park – 44; Blue and John Crow Mtn National Park – 72; Negril EPA – 32; Negril Marine Park – 39; Palisadoes-Port Royal Protected Area – 27; Coral Spring-Mountain Spring – 19; Portland Bight Protected Area – 36; Ocho Rios Protected Areas – 19; Mason River protected Area – 54; Bogue Islands Fish Sanctuary – 14; Bowden Fish Sanctuary – 13; Airport Point Fish Sanctuary – 46; Discovery Bay Fish Sanctuary – 34; Bluefields Bay Fish Sanctuary – 33; Orange Bay Fish Sanctuary – 36; Galeon Bay Fish Sanctuary – 30; Salt Harbour Fish Sanctuary – 36; Galleon Harb

Outcome 1 1.2 mechanism for Revolving Fund 1.5. Operationalization of the National Trust Fund - Establishment of the Board - Signing of Vertical Agreement - Establishment of financing 1.5 At least 4 Project Board Meetings held 1.6. Additional 6 PAs with Business Plans making the total 8 PAs Outcome 2 2.2 Draft overarching policy for the entire protected area system including private lands. 2.3 Marine Spatial Plan completed (supports final target) 2.4 Drafting Instructions for Overarching Legislation prepared Outcome 3 3.1 Fifteen percent increase (based on baseline) in METT scores for 16 PAs 3.3. Additional 4 PAs with management plans making the total 8 PAs

As of 4th quarter Outcome 1 1.2 Mechanisms for Revolving Fund not completed but underway 1.5 National Conservation Trust Fund of Jamaica Board established Outcome 2 2.2. Draft Overarching policy reviewed and updated 2.3. Draft Marine Spatial Plan completed 2.4 Drafting Instructions for Overarching Legislation for PAs prepared Outcome 3 3.1.When the baseline and Mid-Project Scores are compared. The number of PAs with high scores increased by 3.1% (6.3%), while the number of PAs with medium scores increased by 28.1% (28.1%). Consequently, the number of PAs with low scores decreased by 31.2% (62.6%). Figure in brackets represent end of project targets. 3.2 6 Management Plans completed; 2 still outstanding

description.narrative: Increase in NSPA financial capacity measured by Financial Sustainability Scorecard

comment.narrative: Financial Score (Part 2): 53

Financial Score (Part 2): 122
(The highest score possible is 225)
The revised target includes that the highest score possible is 225. The Financial Sustainability scorecard will be applied to the project's mid term evaluation.

description.narrative: Area of Closed Broad-leaf Forest within NPAS sustained

comment.narrative: Broad-leaf: 88,000 hectares
No change in area of Closed Broad-leaf Forest: 88,000 hectares
The most current data is unavailable, however there is data for the 2012-2013 period which reflects a decrease of approximately 4,000 hectares.

description.narrative: Area of living reef within 10 NPAS monitoring sites sustained

comment.narrative: Area of Reef: 3% - 30% living
No change in Area of Reef: 3% - 30% living
The most current data is unavailable, however there is data for the 2012-2013 period which reflects no change in the area of living reef. There was 3%- 30% living reef.

description.narrative:
Population of 4 indicator species sustained in PAs proposed to be monitored:
1. Endemic Giant Swallowtail Butterfly (Pterouus humerus)
2. Queen Conch (Strombus gigas)
3. Black Bill Parrot (Amazona agilis)
4.Yellow Bill Parrot (Amazona collaria)

comment.narrative:
Number of individuals of:
endemic Giant Swallowtail Butterfly (Pterouus humerus), endemic Jamaican BlackBird (Nesopsar niggerrimus), Hawksbill Turtle (Eretmochelys imbricate), and Queen Conch (Strombus gigas) (exact figures to be determined at project inception)

Distribution and Density of endemic Swallowtail Butterfly same as baseline data
No change in Queen Conch: Depth Strata (metres)
0 -10 – 243 conch/hectare
10-20 - 145 conch/hectare
20-30 – 165 conch/hectare
Biomass estimate – 12,214 metric tonne
Current data is unavailable, however a survey is to be done for the biomass of Queen Conch and the report should be available by early 2016.

description.narrative: Number of PAs with business plans that reflect NPAS standards

comment.narrative: 0 PAs with business plans that reflect NPAS standards

8 PAs with business plans that reflect NPAS standards
(25% increase)
Four business plans have been completed, but require revisions based on the recommendations of the Project Steering Committee. The development of four additional business plans is underway.

description.narrative: Local Protected Area Trust Fund 100% established and fully operational by 2016.

comment.narrative: 0 Protected Areas Trust Fund existing locally

Establishment of the Local Trust Fund by 2014.
Operationalization of the Local Trust Fund by 2016.

Local Trust Fund was established in December 2014.
The operationalization process is underway. The National Conservation Trust Fund of Jamaica Board established and endorsed by the relevant Government Minister. Draft By-laws have been completed and will be finalized shortly.

description.narrative: Number of Protected Areas with mechanisms to generate revenue at the site level

comment.narrative: 1 PAs with mechanisms to generate revenue (BJCMNP)
Revenue generation in 5 PAs
1 PA with mechanisms to generate revenue (BJCMNP). However, plans are underway to facilitate the development of revenue generation mechanisms in additional PAs.

description.narrative: Extent to which operational plan for the PA system financial strategy developed.

comment.narrative: No such strategy available.
Operational Plan for the PA system financial strategy developed.
The NPAS Project has procured the services of Global Parks volunteers to facilitate the development of the operational plan for the PA system financial strategy. Completion expected by December 2016.

description.narrative: Number of PAs that contribute to and/or access biological information through CBD Jamaica Clearing House Mechanism (JaCHM).

comment.narrative: One (1) PA contributing to and accessing the CBD JaCHM.
28 PAs and 4 Forest Regions contributing to the JaCHM. Accessing of database and website by end users to include PA Managers (100% of PAs)

Same as in June 2014. Currently the NPAS Project Management Unit is liaising with the JaCHM to ascertain the process for increasing access and/or contributions to the JaCHM on the part of Protected Areas

description.narrative: Extent to which the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) System for NPA management developed.

comment.narrative: 0 M&E system for NPA Management
Monitoring and Evaluation sytem for protected area management developed.

Research is being conducted by the NPAS Biodiversity Conservation Specialist (University of the West Indies, Mona) towards the devlopment of the Monitoring and Evaluation System for Protected Area Management.

description.narrative: Number of PAS with conservation-based economic activities

comment.narrative: 0 PAs with conservation-based economic activities
3 PAs with conservation-based economic activities implemented.

Proposals have been requested from the following protected areas: Pedro Bank, Black River, Gourie Forest Reserve, Port Royal Heritage District and Mason RIver Protected Area. A proposal was received from the Gourie Forest Reserve.

description.narrative: Status of implementation of Communication Strategy for NPAS

comment.narrative: Communication Strategy for NPAS implemented in 20 key PAs

Communication Strategy for NPAS implemented in 7 key PAs. Plans are being finalized to implement the Communication Strategy for NPAS in PAs through various means including Public Service Announcements.

title.narrative: Capacity Development for Energy Efficiency and Security

description.narrative: Capacity Development for Energy Efficiency and Security in Jamaica

title.narrative: Capacity Development for Energy Efficiency and Security project document

description.narrative: Capacity Developed for Energy Efficiency and Security in Jamaica and energy efficiency in the public sector increased.
independent political entity
Energy - power generation

Implementation of National Energy Policy; # of GOJ institutions implementing environmental management systems (EMS); # of financial incentive for energy efficiency; # of energy efficiency plans implemented;

comment.narrative: Jamaica’s National Energy Policy 2009 -2030 which was tabled in Parliament. Subsequently, the Ministry of Energy and Mining produced several supporting documents which provide a strong policy framework and enabling environment for ensuring energy security and efficiency in Jamaica. There is a strong demand and need to ensure policy coherence across institutions and ministries to achieve the targets outlined in the National Energy Policy which includes a reduction in the use of petroleum and an increase in renewable energy.
Construction of the wind turbines Site assessments/selection conducted for deployment of small scale wind turbines Deployment of wind turbines at selected sites

This target was not met as the firm hired to complete the activities related to the targets was said to be in breach of contract. The contract was subsequently terminated and the project recommended to be closed. The activities related to these targets have been subsumed under the GEF 5 project currently being developed by the Country Office.
Conduct project Evaluation

description.narrative: Justice Undertakings for Social Transformation
JUST Output 1
independent political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

% of positions filled; % of equipment and office supplies procured; % of completion of JRIU framework; % of completion of Justice Reform Monitoring and Evaluation Framework; # and type of training and developmental activities completed with officers, directors and managers; % of preliminary research on policy process and capacity; # of consultation activities facilitated; % of completion of Citizens Score Card; # of stakeholder consultations held

comment.narrative: Director recruitment process completed; 25% of equipment and office supplies procured; PMAS training (2009), Training for CMS staff (ongoing), Strategic Planning for Directors (2009); no JRIU framework developed; no Justice Reform M&E framework developed; preliminary research on policy process and capacity not yet started; no consultations facilitated; no Citizens Score Card developed; no stakeholder consultations held

1. One sustainable strategy for justice reform management completed 2. One policy development specialist provided to the MOJ 3. New Corporate Profile and Organizational Structure for the MOJ completed with implementation strategies 4. Youth engagement strategy developed and approved 6. Six entities with M&E Framework 7. At least 60 persons trained in justice reform plans 8. 1 Business Process Re-engineering Tool finalized 9. 2 Actions from communication plan incorporated into MOJ Corporate Plan 10. ICT resources procured for the MOJ 11. Reports on 2 exit polls

1. 1 specialist consultant hired 2. M&E Framework 10% completed 3. 3 Communication Activities adopted and implemented from Corporate Plan 4. Video conferencing solution procured 5. Two exit poll reports completed

description.narrative: While assisting the Government in achieving its priorities and in line with the CPD (2012-2016), UNDP Jamaica is strategically supporting the achievement of inclusive and transformational outcomes within its areas of comparative advantage
Provide targeted assistance to build GOJ capacity to deliver on selected national development priorities in line with the ‘Vision 2030 Jamaica: National Development Plan.
Accountability - local government finance

1) Extent to which the National Strategy for Development Effectiveness developed (fully, partially, not developed) 2) Status of completion of National Consultative Workshops (fully, partially, not done) 3) Percentage of International Development Partners (IDP) in Jamaica consulted for validation 4) Number of International development cooperation summits Jamaica is represented 5) Percent of Implementing Partners assisted in monitoring through validation visits 6) Percentage of quarterly reports received by the CO by the requested deadlines 7) Number of IDP Project Staff trained on RBM 8) Percent of requests from GOJ for technical assistance in M&E fulfilled 9) Percentage of GOJ requests for specialised training for officials facilitated 10) % of participants submitting action plans on applying training for improvement of performance in their MDA 11) Number of initiatives to share knowledge and experience supported 12) Number of international conferences attended by govt officials 13) Number of relevant staff trained in Project Management 14) Percent of relevant entities represented at the high-level sensitization session 15) Number of project proposals developed for submission for funding that relate to government priorities 16) Number of stakeholder consultation sessions conducted that relate to government priorities 17) Number of forums organized to share knowledge and experience on resource mobilization 18) Percentage of proposals successful in securing funding

comment.narrative: 1) National Strategy for Development Effectiveness draft framework developed 2) No National Consultative Workshop for DE Strategy held 3) No International Development Partners (IDP) in Jamaica consulted for validation of Development Effectiveness Strategy 4) No representation at International development cooperation summits by Jamaica 5) No Implementing Partners assisted in monitoring through validation visits 6) 60% of quarterly reports received by the CO by the requested deadline 7) 40 IDP Project Staff trained on RBM 8) No requests from GOJ for technical assistance in M&E fulfilled 9) No GOJ requests for specialised training for officials facilitated 10) No participants submitting action plans on applying training for improvement of performance in their MDA 11) No forums share knowledge and experience held 12) No international conferences attended by govt officials 13) No relevant staff trained in Project Management 14) No entities represented at the high-level sensitization session 15) No proposals developed for submission for funding that relate to government priorities 16) No stakeholder consultation sessions conducted that relate to government priorities 17 No forums organized to share knowledge and experience on resource mobilization 18)No proposals successful in securing funding

Outcome 1 1. The National Strategy for Development Effectiveness completed 2. National Consultative Workshop completed 3. Minimum 80% of IDPs consulted 4. Jamaica is represented at 50% of International high level development cooperation meetings
Outcome 2 1. 100 % of Implementing Partners assisted in monitoring through validation visits 2. 80% of the quarterly report received by the CO before the deadline 3. 80 Project Staff trained on RBM 4. 80 % of requests from GOJ for technical assistance in M&E fulfilled.

title.narrative: National Biodiversity Planning to Support Impl of CBD

description.narrative: National Biodiversity Planning to Support the implementation of the CBD 2011-2020 Strategic Plan in Jamaica
National Biodiversity Planning to Support the implementation of the CBD 2011-2020 Strategic Plan in Jamaica
Environment - policy, planning and administration

Ultimate Outcome: 0.1 Number of SECTORAL planning frameworks including measurable biodiversity conservation and sustainable use targets 0.2 Number of DEVELOPMENT Frameworks including measurable biodiversity conservation and sustainable use targets Outcome1: 1.1 Number of multi-sectoral/multi-stakeholder working groups established to complete the NBSAP 1.2 Number of national targets defined in response to the global Aichi Targets Outcome2: 2.1 Status of NBSAP vis-à-vis the guidance in the CBD Strategic Plan (2011-2020) Outcome3: 3.1 Increase in capacity of the national clearinghouse mechanisms (CHM) to adminster IAS data. Increase in the capacity, technology and financial frameworks for implementing the revised NBSAP; 3.1.1 Extent to which the national invasive alien species database is established. 3.1.2 Status of data online data entry process 3.2. Increase in the capacity, technology and financial frameworks for implementing the revised NBSAP; 3.2.1Extent to which the plan for implementing the NBSAP is developed 3.1 Improvement in international obligation to the CBD 3.1.1 Status of submission of the Fifth National Report to the CBD

comment.narrative: Ultimate Outcome: 0.1 Inclusion of Biodiversity conservation in sectoral planning frameworks as defined in the NBSAP (2003) 0.2 Inclusion of Biodiversity conservation in development frameworks as defined in the NBSAP (2003) Outcome1: 1.1 No working group is established 1.2 Targets defined in NBSAP (2003) not in line with Aitchi Targets Outcome2: 2.1 NBSAP is out of date and does not consider newer biodiversity conservation targets Outcome3: 3.1 CHM is periodically updated and is linked to the CBD site, the CBD’s biosafety portal, bird clearing-house and to other Caribbean and international information and knowledge exchange networks 3.2No framework exists 3.3 Targets outlined in the NBSAP (2003) 3.3.1 Status of Targets as outlined in the Fourth National Report to the CBD

Ultimate Outcome: 0.1.Inclusion of Biodiversity conservation in sectoral planning frameworks for the 11 sectors listed and any additional sectors identified 0.2 Inclusion of Biodiversity conservation in 14 development frameworks listed and any additional sectors identified Outcome1: 1.1 A multi-sectoral/multi-stakeholder working group is established and it completes the stock-taking exercise 1.2 National targets in response to the global Aichi Targets are developed Outcome2: 2.1 Jamaica’s NBSAP fully updated in line with the guidance in the CBD Strategic Plan (2011-2020), the Aitchi targets and submitted to the CBD COP Outcome3: 3.1.1 Update national invasive alien species database which will be periodically updated thereafter 3.2.1 Produce a complete plan for implementing the NBSAP, including capacity, technology and finance needs assessment, that underpins NBSAP implementation 3.3.1 Submission of Fifth National Report to the CBD

Outcome 2 2.1 By the end of 2nd quarter, the 2nd draft of the NBSAP Communication Strategy was finalized and agreed on the outline for the 2011-2020 NBSAP. 2.1 Second draft of the Gap analysis and lessons learned document on the implementation of the first NBSAP and a draft of the supplemental Stocktaking Questionnaire developed. Outcome 3 3.3.1 Logistical support provided for the CHM/IOJ’s National Invasive Species Data and Information Entry Workshop. IT hardware equipment and software procured for the CHM

title.narrative: Support to the Commission of Enquiry

description.narrative: Project developed to facilitate the implementation of community level activities in support of the Commission of Enquiry into the May 2010 events in the West Kingston community of Tivoli Gardens, and its surrounding environs.
Social Cohesion Programme developed.

title.narrative: Support to Bahamas Post Hurricane Joaquin

description.narrative: This project will allow UNDP Jamaica, which covers the Bahamas, to support the identification for short and long term priorities for Recovery and Reconstruction.
Rapid needs assessment to be conducted, which will inform the development of a livelihoods & social sector impact assessment and/or temporary resettlement plan for most affected islands.
